com.fellowshipoftheloosescrews.utilities

Class ThreadedOpModeJob

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.fellowshipoftheloosescrews.utilities.ThreadedOpModeJob
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Runnable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    ThreadingTest

    public abstract class ThreadedOpModeJob
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Runnable
    Created by Thomas on 6/28/2015. This is part of the ThreadedOpMode framework, this is the actual job. Note that this doesn't extend OpMode, so to make it work you have to give it to a ThreadedOpModeWrapper. To register it with the OpModeRegister, use a line like this:

    manager.register(new ThreadedOpModeWrapper(new YOUR_OPMODE_CLASS()));

    There are several examples in the com.fellowshipoftheloosescrews.opmodes package

      ThreadedOpModeWrapper opMode
      The parent ThreadedOpModeWrapper object, used to get normal OpMode functionality.

        public abstract void stop()
        Used just like stop() from OpMode

      • run

        public abstract void run()
        Fill this method with your custom thread job. This is run in a concurrent thread, independent of the rest of your OpMode. When the driver presses the stop button on the controller, isRunning will be set to false. Use this to make sure you stop when you should.
        Specified by:
        run in interface java.lang.Runnable

      • setParentOpMode

        public void setParentOpMode(ThreadedOpModeWrapper parentOpMode)
        Sets the parent ThreadedOpModeWrapper
        Parameters:
        parentOpMode - the parent OpMode. This only needs to be set during the constructor of ThreadedOpModeWrapper

      • setIsRunning

        public void setIsRunning(boolean isRunning)
        This is used to check if the OpMode thread is being told to stop.
        Parameters:
        isRunning - true after start(), but false after stop()

      • isRunning

        public boolean isRunning()
        If the current job is running. This is set to false when the wrapper finishes. Make sure you check this if you're using an infinite loop!

        For example, if you want to keep adding one to a variable in a loop, you could do something like this: while(isRunning())
        {
        x++;
        }

        Or just make sure that you check if it's false in your code at various points

        while(true)
        {
        x++;
        if(!isRunning())
        return;
        }
        Returns:
        If the thread can continue running.

      • sleep

        protected void sleep(int milliseconds)
        Sleeps for a number of milliseconds, this is just a wrapper for Thread.sleep(milliseconds). Use this to make the ThreadedOpModes more readable.
        Parameters:
        milliseconds - the number of milliseconds to sleep

      • sleep

        protected void sleep(int milliseconds,
                     int nanoSeconds)
        same as sleep(milliseconds), but includes the option for nanoseconds.
        Parameters:
        milliseconds - the number of milliseconds to sleep
        nanoSeconds - the number of nanoseconds to sleep
